ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1 hour/week
I spent only a few hours per week reading over the fascinating materials and preparing for the Advocacy and Women's Right's Module.
1 during the module
0 hour (except during the module where it was at least 2 hours for the group project)
During the module weeks: 1-2 hours. Otherwise there was no outside work.
None
not much at all except during module (1-2 hours)
In the time not during the module, I did not spend any time outside of the seminar. During the module, we may have spent five hours for two different weeks.
2 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Global Health Seminar provides a variety of lectures on important global health issues, but the information is presented in a manner that makes it challenging for students to engage with the information being given. The lectures are not strung together in a meaningful order, so it is hard to walk away from the course with a new perspective on global health. The information being presented is important and a good foundation for understanding public health, but it could be presented in a more thoughtful way.

The greatest strength of this course is its ability to draw a wide range of experts from different backgrounds and specialities to describe current issues in Global Health. Many of the speakers were incredible, although the ones that impacted me most were Stephen Lewis and Albert Ko. The course may be improved by hosting discussion sections before the presentations to discuss the readings and prepare to ask in-depth questions to presenters.
Get rid of the module. Have the speakers every other week.

I really enjoyed the speaker series that was a part of this course, however I don't think that the module fits very well into this type of non-credit seminar class. It seemed that most students - myself included - were not able to dedicate enough time and energy to the module to make it a worthwhile learning experience because we were balancing our time with other classes for credit and jobs, etc. I would recommend that the GH Seminar just be a speaker series in the future. The types of projects that the modules covered could be a part of another optional class for credit.

It tries to appeal to everyone and by doing so appeals overall to no one. There are some topics that people are interested in and some that people are not interested in.The module is a great idea but could be done better. This semester the module was also at least better done than the previous semester. When I've attended 0 credit seminars for my previous degree, there were just speakers you listened to and asked questions. A seminar with both speakers and module portion (which requires more work even though it is stated that it doesn't) is just more work than necessary.In terms of the presentation, people should be kept on track and not go much over their 10 minute allotted time.Speakers should only have 1 hour to speak and then a half hour for dinner since the seminar is after business hours.Also having required readings is not useful if you aren't going to discuss them as a part of the speaker/module.
It introduces you to the different paths available to somebody wanting to work in global health.

Great speakers, excellent subject matter and useful topics covered. Module was very well executed and gave us the opportunity to have small group discussions with experts in the field of women's health/rights.Weaknesses: Not much chance to get to hear about other student's experiences abroad and share those in a discussion-type setting. A smaller class size would be more conducive to informative class discussions.
I really enjoyed the GH seminar and learned a lot from the various speakers.

Strengths:The seminars were really interesting. I also liked the opportunity to meet the speakers in information sessions. Some of the presentations provided a great overview of a topic. The seminar helped to understand what global health encompasses.Weaknesses:I did't think the seminar was organized in a logical order. It could have been better to have each presentation build on or at least relate to the other from the week before.
Needs substantial work. Does not provide a good overview of global health. Seems disjointed, little opportunity for feedback or participation.
excellent.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Mike Skonieczny was a great instructor for the course - he was present and engaged at all of the lectures, and he truly valued feedback from the class on how to make the course better for future years. He was easily approachable and a great mentor for many of the students in the class.

Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Michael Skonieczny was an excellent moderator, but a rather peripheral figure to the guest speakers and assistants who helped coordinate the modules. To be honest, I can say very little of Skonieczny as a professor.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  I didn't have much interaction but I did enjoy the speakers he brought in this semester.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Excellent communicator and adviser. Very knowledgeable about the field of global health.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Extremely professional, approachable and receptive to students interests, concerns, requests regarding the course.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  He's great!
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  He was a good host and clearly cares that the global health seminar is well received and worthwhile.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  excellent. very enthusiastic for the topics discussed.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This was a good foundation for the type of global health work being done, but you really get out of this course whatever you put into it.
I would recommend this course to EVERY STUDENT INTERESTED IN GLOBAL HEALTH!

As long as you are not taking it for requirement, there are some great speakers depending on your interests. However, as a requirement, there is additional work for the module component. There is no discussion or application of the problems in Global Health being addressed aside from what speakers are working on.
Yes - very informative exposure to current global public health issues and practitioners.
I would recommend the global health seminar. It is a greatway to gain an understanding of the breadth of global health and spend time with people who have similar interests.
excellent. recommendable to all MPH students.
